rationale: FinPos presents an implementation-relevant architecture for position-aware LLM trading decisions, with clear module boundaries (signal processing, direction, quantity/risk) and useful reward-design ideas. However, immediate autonomous production deployment is not justified because statistical robustness is limited, execution-friction realism is incomplete, prompt sensitivity is high, and the evaluation scope is narrow.
rejection_reasons: Reject immediate autonomous live deployment due to missing production-grade transaction-cost/slippage/impact modeling in headline evaluation.
Reject production promotion without confidence intervals and broader repeated-window robustness evidence.
Reject broad generalization claims because experiments are single-asset oriented and concentrated on a limited stock universe.
Reject high-stakes usage without stronger deterministic reproducibility artifacts (prompt/data/version manifests).
recommendations: Implement the architecture as a reproducible research harness with explicit position-state simulation and auditable decision traces.
Add deterministic manifests: prompt hashes, data snapshot hashes, dependency versions, and run provenance.
Re-evaluate all methods under identical execution-friction assumptions and standardized baseline prompt constraints.
Run walk-forward multi-regime tests with confidence intervals before any promotion beyond paper trading.
Maintain hard risk controls and manual oversight for all non-simulated usage paths.
follow_up_actions: Reproduce Table 1 and Table 2 with fully versioned manifests and verify metric consistency.
Add transaction cost, spread, slippage, and latency models and recompute CR/SR/MDD deltas.
Execute regime-stratified testing (bull, bear, sideways) and report uncertainty bands.
Extend from single-asset decisions to constrained portfolio simulation with concentration and turnover limits.
Audit baseline fairness where setup descriptions differ (for example backbone declarations versus runtime model statements).
